actions.args: {"id": 25, "body": {"name": "Nearblocks.io Proposal for KitWallet Transition", "summary": "With our extensive experience in indexing and integration, we are well-positioned to ensure a seamless transition for KitWallet.", "category": "Infrastructure Committee", "timeline": {"status": "REVIEW", "sponsor_requested_review": false, "reviewer_completed_attestation": false}, "linked_rfp": 1, "supervisor": null, "description": "Dear Infra Committee,\\\\n\\\\nWe appreciate the opportunity to submit our proposal for the transition project and are confident that Nearblocks.io is the ideal partner for this endeavour. With our extensive experience in indexing and integration, we are well-positioned to ensure a seamless transition for KitWallet.\\\\n\\\\n## Response to Requirements\\\\n\\\\nAt Nearblocks.io, we have already created drop-in replaceable KitWallet endpoints, which means there will be no need to build additional infrastructure.\\\\n\\\\nCurrently, two wallets already use our endpoint:\\\\n\\\\nMyNEARWallet:\\\\n\\\\n![nearblocks_meteor](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/365e8d8f-6b7d-44e9-bd22-668831a1b847)\\\\n\\\\nMeteor Wallet:\\\\n![nearblocks_mynearwallet](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4a333b29-6f00-450e-9d74-708fd354369a)\\\\n\\\\nA transition plan would simply be updating `https://api.kitwallet.app/` to `https://api.nearblocks.io/v1/kitwallet/`.\\\\n\\\\nThis gives us a distinct advantage in terms of efficiency and speed for this transition. Our ongoing communication with members of the Pagoda team & infrastructure committee further reinforces our commitment to staying aligned with the ecosystem.\\\\n\\\\nNearblocks is built on top of Near Lake as the data source and currently operates as the #1 explorer within the ecosystem. We believe Nearblocks is in the best position to support this transition.\\\\n\\\\n**Current live endpoints (documentation):**\\\\n\\\\n- Mainnet: https://api.nearblocks.io/api-docs/#/Kitwallet\\\\n- Testnet: https://api-testnet.nearblocks.io/api-docs/#/Kitwallet\\\\n\\\\n## Service Level\\\\n\\\\n### Monitoring\\\\nWe will set up monitoring with notifications for visualizing API availability. System health and performance are available here: https://status.nearblocks.io. From our status monitor, we can send email and/or Slack notifications to major stakeholders. For reference, Nearblocks has been able to maintain a monthly uptime of 99.83%. We are aiming for 99.99% in the coming weeks.\\\\n\\\\n### Response Time\\\\nAverage response time on the Nearblocks API is now sub-2 seconds. Legacy KitWallet endpoints are using LIKE queries, which are known to be less performant. We have avoided this due to additional indexing.\\\\n\\\\nCurrent caveat: `likelyTokens` only supports tokens which Nearblocks supports. This includes all NEP-141 tokens and *most* [legacy tokens](https://github.com/Nearblocks/nearblocks/tree/main/apps/indexer-events/src/services/contracts/ft). We are constantly working to add missing [legacy tokens](https://github.com/Nearblocks/nearblocks/issues/new?assignees=&labels=&projects=&template=token_request.md&title=).\\\\n\\\\n### Rate Limiting\\\\nNearblocks API rate limiting is enforced by IP address and API keys. Given this is a public good endpoint, we will limit 150 queries per minute per IP address. We believe this should be within a very generous fair usage policy. This can be made flexible and is open for discussion.\\\\n\\\\n### Support\\\\n- Support Availability: GitHub issues available here https://github.com/Nearblocks/nearblocks/issues \\\\n- Response Time: 24-48 hours through GitHub issues.\\\\n\\\\n### Data Integrity\\\\nThe KitWallet endpoints are backed by existing Nearblocks data, which is indexed from Near Lake.\\\\n\\\\n### Updates and Changes\\\\nWe have no plans to make changes to KitWallet endpoints. We previously created these endpoints to support drop-in replacements without any work required other than replacing the endpoint.\\\\n\\\\n### Usage\\\\nWe will track KitWallet usage through the Nearblocks API key dashboard for real-time usage. This can be made available to stakeholders.\\\\n\\\\n![API Usage Dashboard](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ceefc8e0-a74a-4299-8bdb-98258c0f7ca1)\\\\n\\\\n## Approach\\\\n\\\\n1. Move Nearblocks KitWallet endpoints to be accessible from the existing endpoint (i.e., https://api.kitwallet.app/) to allow for a seamless transition experience with no downtime for any existing users.\\\\n\\\\n2. We are aware that there are remaining unknown users using this legacy endpoint. As we can\\\\\\'t reach out to suggest a transition to alternative solutions, we will set up a landing page on kitwallet.app stating the current situation and directing them to alternative solutions as well as a point of contact that will be monitored. The landing page will explain the KitWallet transition plans with links to:\\\\n\\\\n- Existing Documentation with user guide\\\\n- Support available through GitHub Issues\\\\n- Alternatives like Nearblocks API and FastNear\\\\n\\\\n## Budget\\\\n\\\\n$4,000 / month for 12 months - to ensure excess capacity for additional traffic.\\\\n\\\\n## Experience & Portfolio\\\\n\\\\nNearblocks.io is our flagship product; however, we have built other products in the past on NEAR, such as nearsend.io.\\\\n\\\\nThank you for considering Nearblocks.io. We look forward to the possibility of working together to bring this transition to completion. Please don\\\\\\'t hesitate to reach out with any further questions or clarifications.\\\\n", "linked_proposals": [], "receiver_account": "nearblocks_io.near", "requested_sponsor": "infrastructure-committee.near", "proposal_body_version": "V1", "requested_sponsorship_usd_amount": "48000", "requested_sponsorship_paid_in_currency": "USDC"}, "labels": []}

{"id": 24, "body": {"name": "Mastercard x Mercuryo x NEAR Branded NEAR Debit Cards and DeFi Products", "summary": "This proposal outlines a partnership with Mastercard to develop the best-in-class crypto card offering across multiple chains. Mercuryo will also provide access to its advanced DCA (Dollar-Cost Averaging) products to enhance NEAR\\\\\\'s DeFi applications.\\\\nThis initiative is endorsed by Meteor Wallet, Burrow, Ref Finance, Bitte Wallet, and Here Wallet.\\\\nObjective:\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tLaunch branded debit cards (Here/Hot Wallet & Meteor) within the app.\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tProvide a NEAR debit card that can be integrated into any project.", "category": "Infrastructure Committee", "timeline": {"status": "APPROVED", "sponsor_requested_review": false, "reviewer_completed_attestation": false}, "linked_rfp": null, "supervisor": "trechriron71.near", "description": "**Launches**\\\\nLaunch of embedded and fully customized card program - Here Wallet\\\\nLaunch of embedded and fully customized card program - Meteor\\\\nLaunch of Near branded card as open source for any project to integrate as off ramp - NEAR \\\\nLaunch of Defi Strategy / DCA - Ref / Burrow\\\\nLaunch of NEAR branded card and DCA - Bitte\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n**Endorsements**\\\\nThis proposal is supported by Bitte, Burrow, Ref Finance, Meteor, and Here/Hot Wallet. All teams have signed endorsement letters confirming their intent to integrate the fintech products described herein. (Meteor Wallet provided approval via message to the NEAR Foundation team). Links to endorsement letters will be provided below.\\\\n \\\\nMilestone 1 \\\\u{2013} $15,000\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tLiaise with Here/Hot Wallet, Meteor Wallet, and NEAR for card designs, and secure approval from Mastercard.\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tSet up individual card terminals with Mastercard.\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tFinalize commercial agreements with the mentioned projects for card launches.\\\\nUse of Funds:\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tCover setup fees for card terminals, paid directly to Mastercard.\\\\n \\\\nMilestone 2 \\\\u{2013} $45,000\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tLaunch custom-branded card programs with HOT Wallet and deploy the NEAR ecosystem debit card.\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tMake the NEAR ecosystem debit card available through Mercuryo\\\\u{2019}s widget for all NEAR projects that have integrated on/off-ramp functionality.\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tThis milestone is achieved once card issuance is available to consumers via the client app, validated by NEAR by creating its own card.\\\\nDisclaimer:\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tCards will be issued virtually to EU residents and passport holders.\\\\nUse of Funds:\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tCover integration and development costs to launch branded cards.\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tEnable necessary features from branded widget flows to top-ups with NEAR assets and functionalities like Apple Pay/Google Pay connectivity.\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tThe funds will largely go towards maintenance and card issuance costs, paid directly to Mastercard.\\\\n \\\\nMilestone 3 \\\\u{2013} $20,000\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tDevelop APIs for a white-label integration of cards for the Meteor Wallet team. This includes the setup of APIs and technical documentation. Other Mastercard launches will be widget-based.\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tLaunch Mercuryo\\\\\\'s DeFi-focused products, including DCA for Ref Finance/Burrow.\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tThe milestone is reached once DCA is live for consumers in 150+ markets and the Meteor Card is live for consumers in the EU.\\\\nUse of Funds:\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tCover development costs for setting up APIs for Mastercard\\\\\\'s fully white-labeled solution.\\\\n \\\\nMilestone 4 \\\\u{2013} $15,000\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tCo-marketing campaign with Mastercard x Mercuryo. This includes the development of co-marketing efforts through Mercuryo and Mastercard\\\\u{2019}s social channels, with the goal of hosting a fireside chat.\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tThe milestone is achieved once NEAR, Mercuryo, and Mastercard approve and sign off on the structure and scope.\\\\nUse of Funds:\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tCreate marketing materials, push Mastercard for co-branding opportunities, and organize a fireside chat.\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tThe funds can also be used for launching limited-time campaigns, such as 0-fee promotions.\\\\n \\\\nMilestone 5 \\\\u{2013} $10,000\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tA total of 10,000 debit cards have been issued across the NEAR ecosystem.\\\\nUse of Funds:\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tCover issuance and maintenance costs for a large number of cards.\\\\n \\\\n\\\\n\\\\n**Team Breakdown**\\\\nPascal Kurzawa \\\\u{2013} Senior Sales and Strategy Manager\\\\nPascal is responsible for managing this proposal, overseeing relationships with the NEAR Foundation and NEAR dApps.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nStepan Fedorov \\\\u{2013} Integration Lead\\\\nStepan is in charge of all technical integrations and serves as the primary contact for any tech-related queries.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nArthur Firstov \\\\u{2013} Chief Business Officer (CBO) & Co-Author of the NEAR Proposal\\\\nArthur plays a key role in co-authoring the NEAR proposal, contributing his business expertise.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nBakhrom Sayd \\\\u{2013} Senior Product Manager\\\\nBakhrom is responsible for adding new supported tokens to the platform and gathering valuable product feedback.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nPeter Kelen \\\\u{2013} Commercial Director\\\\nPeter is responsible for overseeing revenue growth, setting targets, ensuring project execution, and managing client acquisition for the NEAR initiative. He also acts as the main point of contact for the card program, leveraging his experience as a former Director at VISA.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nVasil Viktorov \\\\u{2013} Product Lead (Debit Card)\\\\nVasil is in charge of Mercuryo\\\\u{2019}s card program, defining the roadmap, liaising with card providers, negotiating contracts, and incorporating customer feedback into product development.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n**Value Proposition for the NEAR Ecosystem and Projects:**\\\\n1. Revenue Stream:\\\\nThe fee structure can be fully customized to include revenue-sharing components. Note that most neobanks generate significant revenue from their card programs.\\\\n2. Accessibility for Retail Investors and added utility for NEAR DeFi Applications:\\\\nThis plug-and-play fintech product suite (including debit cards, DCA, and on/off ramps) is available free of charge for all NEAR projects. Projects will be able to:\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tSeamlessly move funds into their applications.\\\\n\\\\u{2022}\\\\tEnable users to withdraw profits or earnings via debit cards, making NEAR one of the most accessible ecosystems.\\\\n3. Massive Brand Exposure:\\\\nMastercard will support marketing efforts, including articles in AAA news outlets and co-hosting a fireside chat for NEAR x Mastercard to promote the first ecosystem-branded debit card.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n", "linked_proposals": [], "receiver_account": "p-kurzawa.near", "requested_sponsor": "infrastructure-committee.near", "proposal_body_version": "V1", "requested_sponsorship_usd_amount": "105000", "requested_sponsorship_paid_in_currency": "USDC"}, "labels": ["Onramps / Offramps", "Other"]}

{"data": {"infrastructure-committee.near": {"index": {"notify": "{\\\\\\\"key\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"p-kurzawa.near\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"value\\\\\\\":{\\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"proposal/edit\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"proposal\\\\\\\":24,\\\\\\\"widgetAccountId\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"infrastructure-committee.near\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"notifier\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"trechriron71.near\\\\\\\"}}"}}}}

{"body": {"name": "Ankr Network- Public RPC Endpoint Funding", "summary": "Ankr has been serving the Near Ecosystem by providing over 1B requests per month through our premium tier only. Ankr is looking to introduce the support of our public Near endpoint, a free tier allowing access to 1M requests a day per developer, greatly contributing to the growth of the Near ecosystem.", "category": "Infrastructure Committee", "timeline": {"status": "REVIEW", "sponsor_requested_review": false, "reviewer_completed_attestation": false}, "linked_rfp": 2, "description": "**#Overview**\\\\nAnkr is a pioneer in decentralized web3 infrastructure helping the developers connect to the underlying RPC nodes by creating publicly available RPC endpoints. We focus on enabling global distributions of our servers through bare metal allowing our latency benchmarks to be the lowest in the industry on a global scale. We\\\\u{2019}ve also been focusing on creating a suite of infrastructure tools such as indexing APIs and snapshot as a service.\\\\nWith a strong emphasis on developer experience, we also act as a rollup as a service provider leveraging our expertise in scaling public blockchains supporting over 500B queries on a monthly basis, to bridge our technology into each rollup we support.\\\\n\\\\n**#Organization**\\\\n**Chandler Song** - Co- Founder - CEO\\\\nAttended the University of California, Berkeley and previously work at AWS as a Software Engineer. He co-founded Ankr alongside Stanley and Ryan.\\\\n**Stanley Wu**- Co- Founder - CTO \\\\nPreviously 4th founding engineer of AWS and quickly became Senior SDM L7 right under the AWS CTO.\\\\n**Ryan Fang **-  Co- Founder - COO\\\\nBefore co-founding Ankr, Fang worked in investment banking and private equity, including roles at Morgan Stanley. He graduated from the University of California, Berkeley.\\\\n**Peter Stewart** - Head of Infrastructure\\\\n**Arsalan Evini** - Head of Business Development \\\\n**Amos Lowe** - Assistant Business Development Manager\\\\n\\\\n**#Primary person\\\\u{2019}s contact information**\\\\nAmos Lowe- Assistant Business Development Manager\\\\nTelegram: https://t.me/AmosLowe\\\\nEmail: a.lowe@asphere.xyz\\\\n\\\\n**#Size of the whole team**\\\\n150 team members\\\\n\\\\n**#Size of the engineering team**\\\\n100+\\\\n\\\\n**#Team location**\\\\nSan Francisco, California\\\\n\\\\n**#Body**\\\\nAnkr has been serving the Near Ecosystem by providing over 1B requests per month through our premium tier only. Ankr is looking to introduce the support of our public Near endpoint, a free tier allowing access to 1M requests a day per developer, greatly contributing to the growth of the Near ecosystem.\\\\nThe problem we\\\\u{2019}re solving with our infrastructure solutions are developer fragmentation tooling to build reliant, secure, and fast communication access to Near. Through our RPC technology, we have built a proprietary load-balancer architecture to ensure global scalability and multi-node provider accessibility.\\\\n\\\\n**#Goals / Milestones**\\\\nIn the span of a month, Ankr will sync Near nodes + purchasing and deployment of BareMetal servers in key regions.\\\\n\\\\nUpon receiving a grant from Near, the sole focus would be to deploy node clusters to be able to be accessed by a larger influx of developers as the Near Ecosystem scales towards mass adoption:\\\\n* Nodes deployed in N. America, S. America, Africa, Asia and Europe to increase accessibility\\\\n* Focus on maintaining sub 100 m/s Global latency\\\\n* Growth from 1B Near node queries from Premium API and expected to grow dramatically from Public API access.\\\\n\\\\n**#Competitor Comparison**\\\\nThere is other infrastructure providers on Near however our key difference are:\\\\n* Ankr is using BareMetal (vs cloud dependency).\\\\n* Higher Free request tier (1,000,000 calls per day per dev for free + Archive & Full capabilities).\\\\n* Flat Fee per Requests (whether they are Full, Archive, Trace and Debug).\\\\n* Strong integration with Cloud Partners (Ankr is IP partner with Microsoft, Tencent, GCP, Alibaba and Huawei, helping them launch dedicated node cluster for enterprise users).\\\\n* Support RaaS solution and integration of NearDA.\\\\n* Involvement in DeFi activity participating in TVL boost.\\\\n\\\\n**Node Deployment and Maintenance:** 12,500 $NEAR tokens (50% upfront)\\\\nObjective: Deploy Near nodes in key global regions (N. America, S. America, Africa, Asia, and Europe) and sync them with the Near network.\\\\nUse of Funds: Purchase BareMetal servers and cover initial deployment costs to ensure low-latency access and high performance.\\\\n\\\\n**Infrastructure Enhancement and Scalability:** 12,500 $NEAR tokens (50% at completion)\\\\nObjective: Improve our proprietary load-balancer architecture for enhanced scalability and multi-node provider accessibility.\\\\nUse of Funds: Invest in infrastructure upgrades to handle increased traffic and requests.\\\\n\\\\n**Milestone Payouts:**\\\\n50% Upfront: 12,500 $NEAR tokens  upon approval to cover initial deployment and syncing of Near nodes, and purchase of BareMetal servers.\\\\n50% at Completion: 12,500 $NEAR tokens upon completion of infrastructure enhancement and scalability improvements.\\\\n\\\\n**NOTE:** Current node support will be deprecated in the result of a rejection.", "linked_proposals": [], "receiver_account": "nelsonankr.near", "requested_sponsor": "infrastructure-committee.near", "proposal_body_version": "V1", "requested_sponsorship_usd_amount": "150000", "requested_sponsorship_paid_in_currency": "NEAR"}, "labels": []}

Ankr is looking to introduce the support of our public Near endpoint, a free tier allowing access to 1M requests a day per developer, greatly contributing to the growth of the Near ecosystem.\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\n\\\\u{2014}\\\\u{2014}\\\\u{2014}\\\\\\\\n\\\\\\\\nRead the full proposal and share your feedback on [DevHub](/devhub.near/widget/app?page=proposal&id=27)\\\\\\\"}"}, "index": {"post": "{\\\\\\\"key\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"main\\\\\\\",\\\\\\\"value\\\\\\\":{\\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\":\\\\\\\"md\\\\\\\"}}"}}}}

{"id": 13, "body": {"name": "FastNear: Read-RPC development support", "summary": "This proposal seeks to continue the development of read-rpc as an open-source project, focusing on compensating the two primary developers working on it.", "category": "Infrastructure Committee", "timeline": {"status": "REVIEW", "sponsor_requested_review": false, "reviewer_completed_attestation": false}, "supervisor": "trechriron71.near", "description": "# Read-RPC development support\\\\n\\\\n## Organization\\\\n\\\\n### Primary person\\\\\\'s contact information\\\\nEvgeny Kuzyakov (ek at fastnear.com)\\\\n\\\\n### Size of the whole team\\\\n3 developers\\\\n\\\\n### Size of the engineering team\\\\n3 developers\\\\n\\\\n### Team location\\\\nRemote\\\\n\\\\n### Team background and bios\\\\n\\\\n- Evgeny Kuzyakov (https://github.com/evgenykuzyakov)\\\\n- Bohdan Khorolets (https://github.com/khorolets) \\\\n- Yurii Koba (https://github.com/kobayurii)\\\\n\\\\n## Professional Experience\\\\n\\\\n- Development and maintenance of read-rpc (https://github.com/near/read-rpc)\\\\n- Development and serving of the alternative indexing solution at FASTNEAR, e.g. https://mainnet.neardata.xyz (https://github.com/fastnear/neardata-server/)\\\\n\\\\n## Body\\\\nThe read-rpc project aims to provide a centralized RPC solution for serving read-only requests for NEAR blockchain data. It mimics the json-rpc client from nearcore while supporting archival data and maintaining fast response times with low latency. This proposal seeks to continue the development of read-rpc as an open-source project, focusing on compensating the two primary developers working on it.\\\\n\\\\nKey benefits of continuing read-rpc development in open-source:\\\\n1. Improved access to NEAR blockchain data for developers and applications\\\\n2. Enhanced performance for read-only operations\\\\n3. Support for archival data\\\\n4. Open-source nature promotes transparency and community involvement\\\\n\\\\nThe project development and documentation will remain under the MIT or Apache2 License.\\\\n\\\\n## Goals / Milestones\\\\n\\\\n* Continuous improvement of read-rpc functions.\\\\n    * (4Q2024) Support the upcoming **resharding** on the `nearcore` (10 shards until the EOY2024)\\\\n        * Implement the flawless resharding process (job) to avoid downtimes like `nearcore` does it\\\\n        * We are blocked to start this job until we know the new shard layout (waiting for protocol team information)\\\\n        * Ideally, find a way to automate or at least to simplify this process for the future reshardsings [including the dynamic one]\\\\n    * **(3Q2025) Refactor transaction details storage** to reduce the cost, reduce the vendor-lock and ensure it is backupable [ideally, allowing to backup specific periods]\\\\n        * Protobuf instead of raw JSON to reduce the storage consumption and improve the speed of ser/de\\\\n        * Introduce alternative storages (e.g. database,, filesystem, other object storages)\\\\n    * **(3Q2025) Regular node mode**\\\\n        * Create a garbage collector for the readRPC to drop the older data (blocks, chunks, transactions, etc.)\\\\n        * Allow the configuration of the number of epochs to keep, similar to `nearcore`\\\\n* (4Q2024) Release of the read-rpc with postgres database support (transitioning from ScyllaDB).\\\\n* **(1-2Q2025) Extensive documentation on how to setup read-rpc node from scratch.**\\\\n    * Setup the backups of the necessary data and make it distributable (postgres, blocks, chunks, transaction details) archival and partial (regular)\\\\n    * Setup the distribution of the runnable assets (binaries, Docker images, etc.)\\\\n    * Improve the configuration by simplifying the current version that uses both TOML and env vars \\\\n    * Create the documentation for the node operators\\\\n    * Setup the support channels for the node operators\\\\n* (4Q2024) Ability to sync the readRPC database from alternative indexing sources like neardata.xyz instead of NEAR {"id": 13, "body": {"name": "FastNear: Read-RPC development support", "summary": "This proposal seeks to continue the development of read-rpc as an open-source project, focusing on compensating the two primary developers working on it.", "category": "Infrastructure Committee", "timeline": {"status": "DRAFT"}, "supervisor": "trechriron71.near", "description": "# Read-RPC development support\\\\n\\\\n## Organization\\\\n\\\\n### Primary person\\\\\\'s contact information\\\\nEvgeny Kuzyakov (ek at fastnear.com)\\\\n\\\\n### Size of the whole team\\\\n3 developers\\\\n\\\\n### Size of the engineering team\\\\n3 developers\\\\n\\\\n### Team location\\\\nRemote\\\\n\\\\n### Team background and bios\\\\n\\\\n- Evgeny Kuzyakov (https://github.com/evgenykuzyakov)\\\\n- Bohdan Khorolets (https://github.com/khorolets) \\\\n- Yurii Koba (https://github.com/kobayurii)\\\\n\\\\n## Professional Experience\\\\n\\\\n- Development and maintenance of read-rpc (https://github.com/near/read-rpc)\\\\n- Development and serving of the alternative indexing solution at FASTNEAR, e.g. https://mainnet.neardata.xyz (https://github.com/fastnear/neardata-server/)\\\\n\\\\n## Body\\\\nThe read-rpc project aims to provide a centralized RPC solution for serving read-only requests for NEAR blockchain data. It mimics the json-rpc client from nearcore while supporting archival data and maintaining fast response times with low latency. This proposal seeks to continue the development of read-rpc as an open-source project, focusing on compensating the two primary developers working on it.\\\\n\\\\nKey benefits of continuing read-rpc development in open-source:\\\\n1. Improved access to NEAR blockchain data for developers and applications\\\\n2. Enhanced performance for read-only operations\\\\n3. Support for archival data\\\\n4. Open-source nature promotes transparency and community involvement\\\\n\\\\nThe project development and documentation will remain under the MIT or Apache2 License.\\\\n\\\\n## Goals / Milestones\\\\n\\\\n* Continuous improvement of read-rpc functions.\\\\n    * (4Q2024) Support the upcoming **resharding** on the `nearcore` (10 shards until the EOY2024)\\\\n        * Implement the flawless resharding process (job) to avoid downtimes like `nearcore` does it\\\\n        * We are blocked to start this job until we know the new shard layout (waiting for protocol team information)\\\\n        * Ideally, find a way to automate or at least to simplify this process for the future reshardsings [including the dynamic one]\\\\n    * **(3Q2025) Refactor transaction details storage** to reduce the cost, reduce the vendor-lock and ensure it is backupable [ideally, allowing to backup specific periods]\\\\n        * Protobuf instead of raw JSON to reduce the storage consumption and improve the speed of ser/de\\\\n        * Introduce alternative storages (e.g. database,, filesystem, other object storages)\\\\n    * **(3Q2025) Regular node mode**\\\\n        * Create a garbage collector for the readRPC to drop the older data (blocks, chunks, transactions, etc.)\\\\n        * Allow the configuration of the number of epochs to keep, similar to `nearcore`\\\\n* (4Q2024) Release of the read-rpc with postgres database support (transitioning from ScyllaDB).\\\\n* **(1-2Q2025) Extensive documentation on how to setup read-rpc node from scratch.**\\\\n    * Setup the backups of the necessary data and make it distributable (postgres, blocks, chunks, transaction details) archival and partial (regular)\\\\n    * Setup the distribution of the runnable assets (binaries, Docker images, etc.)\\\\n    * Improve the configuration by simplifying the current version that uses both TOML and env vars \\\\n    * Create the documentation for the node operators\\\\n    * Setup the support channels for the node operators\\\\n* (4Q2024) Ability to sync the readRPC database from alternative indexing sources like neardata.xyz instead of NEAR Lake Framework.\\\\n    * (aspirational) Feature: flawless switch between the sources to improve the uptime\\\\n* 1 year development support of the read-rpc, to maintain parity with the original json-rpc client from nearcore.\\\\n\\\\n## Metrics\\\\n\\\\n* Requests per second benchmarks. **10k requests per second**\\\\n* Database size and hardware requirements. \\\\n    * **DB ~10-15 TB**\\\\n    * **Object Storage for Transaction details ~24TB**\\\\n    * **+ All NEAR Lake/Data (blocks, chunks, etc.)**\\\\n    * **16 CPU/16 GB RAM for rpc server instance**\\\\n    * **4 CPU/8 GB RAM for indexers (2 different ones)**\\\\n    * **DB 8 CPU / 52 GB RAM**\\\\n* Query response time: Measure and maintain low latency for read operations **500 ms**\\\\n* Number of unique users/applications utilizing read-rpc: **2+ operators**\\\\n* Community engagement: Track GitHub stars, forks, and contributions: **30+ stars, 10+ forks**\\\\n\\\\n## Usage & Examples\\\\n- Current users: Pagoda RPC service\\\\n- Usage metrics: unavialble\\\\n\\\\n## Budget\\\\n### Budget Total\\\\n$220,000 USD per year\\\\n#### Payment plan\\\\n- 2024 Q4: $55000 (paid in October)\\\\n- 2025 Q1: $55000 (paid in January)\\\\n- 2025 Q2: $55000 (paid in April)\\\\n- 2025 Q3: $55000 (paid in July)\\\\n\\\\n### Budget Breakdown\\\\n- Developer compensation: $170,000 USD per year\\\\n- Infrastructure cost for tests, benchmarks and development: $50,000 USD per year\\\\n\\\\nThis budget covers the compensation for the two primary developers working on the read-rpc project for one year. {"body": {"name": "Aurora Labs: NEAR Lake", "summary": "Aurora Labs proposes to take over the NEAR Lake service for further maintenance and development.", "category": "Infrastructure Committee", "timeline": {"status": "DRAFT"}, "linked_rfp": 3, "description": "## Organization\\\\n\\\\n### Primary person\\\\u{2019}s contact information\\\\n\\\\nAlex Shevchenko ([alex.shevchenko@aurora.dev](alex.shevchenko@aurora.dev)) - Aurora Labs CEO\\\\n\\\\n### Project DRIs\\\\n\\\\nDimitar Petkov ([dimitar.petkov@aurora.dev](dimitar.petkov@aurora.dev))\\\\nDmitry Strokov ([dmitry.strokov@aurora.dev](dimitar.petkov@aurora.dev))\\\\n\\\\n### Size of the whole team\\\\n\\\\n48 people\\\\n\\\\n### Size of the engineering team\\\\n\\\\n23 people\\\\n\\\\n## Professional Experience\\\\n\\\\n### Examples of relevant experience with NEAR blockchain\\\\n\\\\nAurora Labs\\\\u{2019} engineering team has developed significant expertise in indexing, storing, and distributing blockchain data to meet the demands of internal infrastructure. Over the past two and a half years, the focus has been on building and refining a robust data pipeline designed to deliver maximum speed, high availability, fault tolerance, and efficient global data access.\\\\n\\\\nTo support these capabilities, the team includes engineers with experience in the relevant parts of the nearcore codebase, which enables the maintenance and customization of an in-house version of the NEAR Indexer using the NEAR Indexer Framework. This specialized knowledge has been instrumental in operating instances of nearcores and NEAR Indexers, ensuring that Aurora RPC services consistently achieve high availability and performance.\\\\n\\\\nThe entire infrastructure is continuously monitored and backed-up to maintain optimal performance and reliability across various regions worldwide, aligning with the company\\\\\\'s commitment to delivering resilient and responsive blockchain services.\\\\n\\\\n## Body\\\\n\\\\nThe proposed solution involves adopting the current setup for NEAR Lake from the Pagoda team, with a focus on ensuring reliability and high availability, eliminating potential vulnerabilities, and establishing comprehensive monitoring. The approach includes deploying new or additional indexer instances if necessary to meet failover/latency demands.\\\\n\\\\nAdditionally, there is a plan to potentially integrate the process of writing to NEAR Lake into the existing infrastructure pipeline in the future, aiming to reduce operational costs by reusing data from the indexers for both internal needs of Aurora infrastructure and the needs of NEAR Lake.\\\\n\\\\n## Goals / Milestones\\\\n\\\\n1. Conduct knowledge transfer sessions with the Pagoda team\\\\n2. Take over the ownership of S3 buckets\\\\n3. Deploy new/additional indexers\\\\n4. Set up indexers monitoring\\\\n5. Set up lake progression monitoring\\\\n6. Set up public status-page\\\\n7. Update all relevant documentation, take over support channels\\\\n8. Make announcements, finish the hand-over\\\\n9. (Optional/Later): integrate lake indexer with existing Aurora infrastructure\\\\n\\\\n## Metrics\\\\n\\\\nKey things that have to be tracked:\\\\n- Per-indexer metrics - have to be exported from indexer instances:\\\\n\\\\t- Liveness status\\\\n\\\\t- Sync/unsync status\\\\n\\\\t- Current progression\\\\n\\\\t- Errors\\\\n- Bucket progression metrics - shall be measured by reading from S3 using lake client library (indexer framework):\\\\n\\\\t- Current progression\\\\n\\\\t- Fetching/parsing errors\\\\n\\\\t- Lag from the final block (shall be compared against final block querying from RPC)\\\\n- Total uptime is calculated as: total time when lag was less than 5 blocks\\\\n\\\\nSuccess condition: uptime during the evaluation period is at least 99.9%\\\\n\\\\n## Budget\\\\n\\\\nThe budget might be re-evaluated in future due to:\\\\n\\\\t- Growth of monthly-generated NEAR data\\\\n\\\\t- Pipeline optimizations applied by Aurora Labs team\\\\n\\\\n### Budget total\\\\n\\\\n$35,000 USD per quarter\\\\n\\\\n### Budget Breakdown\\\\n\\\\nS3 costs breakdown:\\\\n- Assuming that:\\\\n  - Pricing model is S3 Standard\\\\n    - Storage cost = 0,0245 USD/month/1GB\\\\n    - PUT cost = 0,0054 USD/1000 requests\\\\n    - LIST cost = 0,0054 USD/1000 requests\\\\n    - GET cost = 0,00043 USD/1000 requests\\\\n  - Every block is represented with 7 objects: 1 header + 6 chunks\\\\n  - Every object is written at most 3 times (failover replication)\\\\n    - Note: replication multiplier can be optimized with some effort\\\\n  - Readers are paying for themself\\\\n  - There\\\\u{2019}s 3 progression trackers per network (failover replication) that are reading continuously\\\\n    - Note: replication multiplier can be optimized with some effort\\\\n  - 6TB of data is written every month in average (during 1 year period)\\\\n- Storage cost:\\\\n  - Current storage: 40TB\\\\n  - Storage after 1 year: 40TB + 6TB * 12months = 112TB\\\\n  - Average (during 1 year) monthly storage: (40TB + 112TB) / 2 = 76TB\\\\n  - Average (during 1 year) monthly storage cost: 76TB * 1024 * 0.0245 USD/month/GB = 1907 USD\\\\n  - First year storage cost = 12 * 1907 USD = 22884 USD\\\\n- Blocks per year per network = 365 * 24 * 3600 / 1.2 = 26280000 blocks\\\\n- Objects per year per network = 26280000 blocks * 7 objects = 183960000 objects\\\\n- Write cost:\\\\n  - Writes cost per year per network per instance = 183960000 / 1000 * 0.0054 USD = 993 USD\\\\n  - Total writes cost per year = 1987 USD * 2 networks * 3 replicas = 5958 USD\\\\n- Read cost:\\\\n  - LIST requests per year per network per instance = 183960000 objects / 1000 = 183960 requests\\\\n  - LIST cost per year per network per instance = 183960 / 1000 * 0.0054 USD = 1 USD\\\\n  - GET cost per year per per network instance = 183960000 objects / 1000 * 0.00043 USD = 79 USD\\\\n  - Read cost per year per network per instance = 1 USD + 79 USD = 80 USD\\\\n  - Total read cost per year = 80 USD * 2 networks * 3 replicas = 480 USD\\\\n- Total S3 cost per year = 22884 USD + 5958 USD + 480 USD ~= $30k USD\\\\n\\\\nHardware costs:\\\\n- The optimal fit for one indexer is (for example) Hetzner AX52 with +2+2TB (raid-1) NVME SSD:\\\\n  - Monthly cost: 125 USD\\\\n  - Setup fee: 51 USD\\\\n  - Yearly cost: 51 + 125 * 12 = 1551 USD\\\\n- Total machines needed:\\\\n  - Indexers: 2 networks * 3 replicas = 6\\\\n  - Progression trackers/etc: collocated with other services on different machines, but is equivalent of 1 more machine\\\\n  - 7 machines in total\\\\n- Total cost per year: 7 machines * 1551 USD ~= $11k USD\\\\n\\\\nOperational overhead and safety margin:\\\\n- $8k / month ~= $96k / year\\\\n\\\\nTotal cost for the first year = $30k + $11k + $96k = ~$137k\\\\n\\\\nWe propose to structure the contract with quarterly payments: $35k/quarter\\\\n", "linked_proposals": [], "receiver_account": "aurorafinance.sputnik-dao.near", "requested_sponsor": "infrastructure-committee.near", "proposal_body_version": "V1", "requested_sponsorship_usd_amount": "35000", "requested_sponsorship_paid_in_currency": "USDC"}, "labels": []}

{"body": {"name": "Professional and efficient Infra support for Near Lake, 24/7 operation, monitor", "summary": "As an infrastructure service provider with ties to Near (Hackathon winner, Grants winner), we aim to efficiently manage the operations of Near Lake, providing the most essential infrastructure services for the Near ecosystem. At the same time, since we are already providing professional RPC services for Near, operating external Near Lake RPC nodes is also within our capabilities.\\\\n", "category": "Infrastructure Committee", "timeline": {"status": "REVIEW", "sponsor_requested_review": false, "reviewer_completed_attestation": false}, "linked_rfp": 3, "description": "**Team Background and Professional Experience**\\\\nZhihao, CEO\\\\nMadao, CTO\\\\nLea, CMO\\\\nBowen, COO\\\\nAlbert, Chief Scientist\\\\n\\\\nBlockPI is a blockchain technology infrastructure service provider, primarily offering RPC services and data indexing services. The team has 8 years of experience in developing and operating internet infrastructure. And BlockPI RPC service has been live since Oct 2022. The team is mainly based in China and Canada. 20 persons in total, all are passionate about the web3 industry.\\\\n\\\\nAmong the team:\\\\nCore development team: 7 professionals\\\\nDesign, UX/UI: 2 professionals\\\\nProject Management: 2 professionals\\\\nOperation: 2 professionals\\\\nBD / Marketing/Customer Support: 7 professionals\\\\nThe team consists of experienced full-stack engineers with extensive experience in infrastructure development and operations, including network protocols, and is also familiar with AWS S3 configuration and operations. BlockPI\\\\\\'s RPC services are well-regarded in the industry for their excellent performance and stable service. Main works:\\\\n\\\\n1. RPC service: https://blockpi.io/\\\\n2. AA explorer: https://aaexplorer.com/live-statistics; https://github.com/BlockPILabs/aaexplorer\\\\n3. UserOps indexer: https://github.com/BlockPILabs/erc4337_user_operation_indexer\\\\n4. RPC aggregator: https://rpchub.io/; https://github.com/BlockPILabs/aggregator\\\\nIn 2021, we won second place at the Near Global Hackathon, where our award-winning demo was the precursor to BlockPI\\\\\\'s distributed RPC service. Subsequently, we received grants from Near to provide basic RPC services. We have also obtained funding from other ecosystems to offer RPC services and ERC4337 services, including the development of related indexers.\\\\nAs an infrastructure service provider with ties to Near, we want to efficiently manage the operations of Near Lake, providing the most essential infrastructure services for the Near ecosystem.\\\\n\\\\nAffiliations with other NEAR ecosystem partners:\\\\nRef.finance (https://www.ref.finance/) (Reference: Marco, Bowen)\\\\nOctopus network (https://oct.network/) (Reference: Liu Yi)\\\\nNearblocks.io (Reference: https://t.me/devluke)\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n**Deployment Plan**\\\\n1. The core Near Lake data buckets will continue to be maintained on AWS S3. Due to the large volume and high importance of Near Lake data, we believe that S3 is the most suitable option. We will work with Pagoda on the transition steps in AWS and conduct the necessary testing. We will use Stadard Storage tier for S3 and the same configuration to ensure that the user experience for Near Lake is identical to that before the handover.\\\\n2. The peripheral indexer RPC nodes will be deployed on Baremetal servers procured by BlockPI. We will deploy two nodes for each network in Europe, ensuring resource redundancy. Using Baremetal has two advantages: distributed deployment ensures service robustness and maintains a high SLA, and it is also cost-effective.\\\\n3. We will monitor the Near Lake S3 and the Indexer RPC nodes separately to perform RCA in the event of block height delays.\\\\n4. In addition to automated monitoring and alerting processes, we also have dedicated user support channels. We will create a dedicated customer support channel for Near on Discord. The existing ticket system allows users to submit related issues. For more details, please refer to https://blockpi.io/ticket.\\\\n \\\\n**Monitoring and Status page**\\\\n\\\\nOur Prometheus configuration includes detailed alert rules, covering various aspects from infrastructure to application layers. The Nightingale configuration ensures the prioritization and effective distribution of alerts. Our on-call team uses FlashDuty for shift scheduling, ensuring 24/7 response capability.\\\\n\\\\nWe have our own status page, and we can add Near Lake to it or develop a separate status page specifically for Near Lake. We can set the comparison to BlockPI Near RPC and others. If lag from the final block of the NEAR Lake is less than five blocks behind the last finalized block on NEAR RPC, we will make the appropriate markings and issue alerts. Please refer to https://status.blockpi.io/\\\\n\\\\n**Milestones**\\\\nMilestone #1: Complete S3 Transition\\\\n\\\\nObject: Successfully deploy the mainnet and testnet S3 bucket, finish testing, and ensure that the service performance is identical to that before the transfer.\\\\n\\\\nTime: 10 days after receiving the first grant.
